Welikala\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Denys Wilkinson Building, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"L. Yan\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"ESAC, ESA, PO Box 78, Villanueva de la Ca\u00f1ada, 28691 Madrid, Spain\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Planck\u2019s dusty GEMS: The brightest gravitationally lensed galaxies discovered with the Planck all-sky survey\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2015/09/16\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2015/09/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"581\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A105\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2015A%26A...581A.105C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2015/09/aa25128-14.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We present an analysis of CO spectroscopy and infrared-to-millimetre dust photometry of 11 exceptionally bright far-infrared (FIR) and sub-mm sources discovered through a combination of the &lt;i&gt;Planck &lt;i/&gt;all-sky survey and follow-up &lt;i&gt;Herschel-SPIRE &lt;i/&gt;imaging \u2013 \u201c&lt;i&gt;Planck&lt;i/&gt;\u2019s Dusty Gravitationally Enhanced subMillimetre Sources\u201d. Each source has a secure spectroscopic redshift &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; = 2.2\u20133.6 from multiple lines obtained through a blind redshift search with EMIR at the IRAM 30-m telescope. Interferometry was obtained at IRAM and the SMA, and along with optical/near-infrared imaging obtained at the CFHT and the VLT reveal morphologies consistent with strongly gravitationally lensed sources, including several giant arcs. Additional photometry was obtained with JCMT/SCUBA-2 and IRAM/GISMO at 850 &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;m and 2 mm, respectively. The SEDs of our sources peak near either the 350 &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;m or 500 &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;m bands of SPIRE with peak flux densities between 0.35 and 1.14 Jy. All objects are extremely bright isolated point sources in the 18\u2032\u2032 beam of SPIREat 250 &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;m, with apparent FIR luminosities of up to 3 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; (not correcting for the lensing effect). Their morphologies, sizes, CO line widths, CO luminosities, dust temperatures, and FIR luminosities provide additional empirical evidence that these are amongst the brightest strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies on the sub-mm sky. Our programme extends the successful wide-area searches for strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies (carried out with the South Pole Telescope and &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt;) towards even brighter sources, which are so rare that their systematic identification requires a genuine all-sky survey like &lt;i&gt;Planck&lt;i/&gt;. Six sources are above the \u2243600 mJy 90% completeness limit of the &lt;i&gt;Planck &lt;i/&gt;catalogue of compact sources (PCCS) at 545 and 857 GHz, which implies that these must literally be amongst the brightest high-redshift FIR and sub-mm sources on the extragalactic sky. We discuss their dust masses and temperatures, and use additional WISE 22-&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;m photometry and template fitting to rule out a significant contribution of AGN heating to the total infrared luminosity. Six sources are detected in FIRST at 1.4 GHz, and the others have sensitive upper limits. Four have flux densities brighter than expected from the local FIR-radio correlation, but in the range previously found for high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; sub-mm galaxies, one has a deficit of FIR emission, and 6 are consistent with the local correlation, although this includes 3 galaxies with upper limits. We attribute this to the turbulent interstellar medium of these galaxies, rather than the presence of radio AGN. The global dust-to-gas ratios and star-formation efficiencies of our sources are predominantly in the range expected from massive, metal-rich, intense, high-redshift starbursts. An extensive multi-wavelength follow-up programme is being carried out to further characterize these sources and the intense star formation within them.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=D.         data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n Ca&#241;ameras</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup>, <span id=\"aa25128-14-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">N. P. H. Soucail</span><sup>8</sup><sup>,9</sup>, <span id=\"aa25128-14-author-31\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128&amp;n=31\" class=\"author\">I. Valtchanov</span><sup>13</sup>, <span id=\"aa25128-14-author-32\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128&amp;n=32\" class=\"author\">N. Welikala</span><sup>20</sup> and <span id=\"aa25128-14-author-33\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128&amp;n=33\" class=\"author\">L. Yan</span><sup>13</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\">\n          <sup>1</sup> \n           \n            Institut d&#8217;Astrophysique Spatiale, UMR 8617, Universit&#233;\n              Paris-Sud,\n            B&#226;t. 121,\n             91405 \n             Orsay,\n             France \n           \n        <br>\n          <sup>2</sup> \n           CNRS,  91405 \n             Orsay,\n             France \n        <br>\n          <sup>3</sup> \n           Institut Universitaire de France,  Paris,  France \n        <br>\n          <sup>4</sup> \n          Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of British\n              66 Columbia,  6224 Agricultural\n              Road,  Vancouver,\n            British Columbia, 58 \n             Canada \n        <br>\n          <sup>5</sup> \n           Institut de Radio Astronomie Millim&#233;trique (IRAM), 300 rue de la\n              Piscine, Domaine Universitaire,  38406 Saint-Martin d&#8217;H&#232;res,  France \n        <br>\n          <sup>6</sup> \n           Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics,\n               Cambridge,  MA \n             02138,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>7</sup> \n          Steward Observatory, University of Arizona,\n               Tucson,  AZ \n             85721,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>8</sup> \n          Universit&#233; de Toulouse, UMS-OMP, IRAP,   31028 \n             Toulouse Cedex 4,\n               France \n        <br>\n          <sup>9</sup> \n          CNRS, IRAP, 9\n              Av. colonel Roche,  BP\n              44346,  31028 \n             Toulouse Cedex 4,\n               France \n        <br>\n          <sup>10</sup> \n          INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova,  Vicolo dell&#8217;Osservatorio\n              5,  35122 \n             Padova,\n             Italy \n        <br>\n          <sup>11</sup> \n           CEA-Saclay,  91191 \n             Gif-sur-Yvette,\n               France \n        <br>\n          <sup>12</sup> \n          Aix-Marseille Universit&#233;, CNRS, LAM (Laboratoire d&#8217;Astrophysique\n              de Marseille) UMR 7326,  13388 \n             Marseille,\n             France \n        <br>\n          <sup>13</sup> \n          ESAC, ESA,  PO Box 78,  Villanueva de la Ca&#241;ada,\n               28691 \n             Madrid,\n             Spain \n        <br>\n          <sup>14</sup> \n          Infrared Processing and Analysis Center, California Institute of\n              Technology,  Pasadena,\n               CA \n             91125,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>15</sup> \n           European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarzschild Str. 2,  85748 \n             Garching,\n             Germany \n        <br>\n          <sup>16</sup> \n           European Southern Observatory, ESO Vitacura, Alonso de Cordova 3107, Vitacura, Casilla \n               19001,  Santiago,\n               Chile \n        <br>\n          <sup>17</sup> \n          Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, ALMA Santiago\n            Central Offices, Alonso de Cordova 3107, Vitacura, Casilla   763-0355,\n               Santiago,\n             Chile \n        <br>\n          <sup>18</sup> \n          School of Earth and Space Exploration, Arizona State\n              University,  Tempe,\n               AZ \n             85287,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>19</sup> \n          UPMC Univ. Paris 06, UMR 7095, Institut d&#8217;Astrophysique de\n              Paris,  75014 \n             Paris,\n             France \n        <br>\n          <sup>20</sup> \n          Department of Physics, University of Oxford,\n              Denys Wilkinson Building, Keble\n              Road,  Oxford \n             OX1 3RH,\n             UK \n        <br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>8 October 2014<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>5 June 2015</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p>We present an analysis of CO spectroscopy and infrared-to-millimetre dust photometry of 11 exceptionally bright far-infrared (FIR) and sub-mm sources discovered through a combination of the <i>Planck </i>all-sky survey and follow-up <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>imaging &#8211; &#8220;<i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty Gravitationally Enhanced subMillimetre Sources&#8221;. Each source has a secure spectroscopic redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.2</span>&#8211;3.6 from multiple lines obtained through a blind redshift search with EMIR at the IRAM 30-m telescope. Interferometry was obtained at IRAM and the SMA, and along with optical/near-infrared imaging obtained at the CFHT and the VLT reveal morphologies consistent with strongly gravitationally lensed sources, including several giant arcs. Additional photometry was obtained with JCMT/SCUBA-2 and IRAM/GISMO at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 2 mm, respectively. The SEDs of our sources peak near either the 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m or 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m bands of SPIRE with peak flux densities between 0.35 and 1.14 Jy. All objects are extremely bright isolated point sources in the 18<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam of SPIREat 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, with apparent FIR luminosities of up to <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &#215; 10<sup>14</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (not correcting for the lensing effect). Their morphologies, sizes, CO line widths, CO luminosities, dust temperatures, and FIR luminosities provide additional empirical evidence that these are amongst the brightest strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies on the sub-mm sky. Our programme extends the successful wide-area searches for strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies (carried out with the South Pole Telescope and <i>Herschel</i>) towards even brighter sources, which are so rare that their systematic identification requires a genuine all-sky survey like <i>Planck</i>. Six sources are above the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8771;</span>600 mJy 90% completeness limit of the <i>Planck </i>catalogue of compact sources (PCCS) at 545 and 857 GHz, which implies that these must literally be amongst the brightest high-redshift FIR and sub-mm sources on the extragalactic sky. We discuss their dust masses and temperatures, and use additional WISE 22-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m photometry and template fitting to rule out a significant contribution of AGN heating to the total infrared luminosity. Six sources are detected in FIRST at 1.4 GHz, and the others have sensitive upper limits. Four have flux densities brighter than expected from the local FIR-radio correlation, but in the range previously found for high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> sub-mm galaxies, one has a deficit of FIR emission, and 6 are consistent with the local correlation, although this includes 3 galaxies with upper limits. We attribute this to the turbulent interstellar medium of these galaxies, rather than the presence of radio AGN. The global dust-to-gas ratios and star-formation efficiencies of our sources are predominantly in the range expected from massive, metal-rich, intense, high-redshift starbursts. An extensive multi-wavelength follow-up programme is being carried out to further characterize these sources and the intense star formation within them.</p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>galaxies: high-redshift / galaxies: star formation / galaxies: starburst / submillimeter: galaxies / gravitational lensing: strong / galaxies: formation</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Based on observations collected with the <i>Herschel </i>and <i>Planck </i>satellites, IRAM, SMA, JCMT, CFHT, and the VLT.</p>\n</div>\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>&#8902;&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Corresponding author: N. Nesvadba,  e-mail: nicole.nesvadba@ias.u-psud.fr</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2015</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>The brightest, most strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies in the high-redshift Universe have an extraordinary potential to advance our understanding of the processes that regulate the growth of the most massive galaxies we see today. In particularly fortuitous cases, gravitational lensing from massive, intervening galaxies, or galaxy clusters not only boosts the apparent integrated brightness of high-redshift galaxies by factors up to 20&#8211;60, but also magnifies their images by similar factors while conserving surface brightness. Thereby, they allow us to study the fine spatial details of intensely star-forming high-redshift galaxies at scales much below 1 kpc, down to around 100 pc (e.g., <a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R85\">Swinbank et al. 2010</a>, <a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R86\">2011</a>). This is more akin to the scales of individual star-forming regions in nearby galaxies than the galaxy-wide scales (of order a few kpc) with which we must otherwise content ourselves at cosmological distances. </p>\n<p>Since the discovery of the first gravitationally lensed galaxy in the optical (<a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R82\">Soucail et al. 1987</a>; the first gravitationally lensed quasar had already been discovered by <a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R91\">Walsh et al. 1979</a>), strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies have been identified and studied in all wavebands from the ground and in space. Strongly gravitationally lensed sub-mm galaxies provide an extraordinary possibility to probe individual star-forming regions in the most intensely star-forming high-redshift galaxies. They are also very promising sources for increasing our understanding of how the deep gravitational potential well of high-redshift galaxies, their high gas fractions and gas-mass surface densities, and feedback from star formation and perhaps active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are setting the stage for the intense star formation at fine spatial detail (e.g., <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R19\">Danielson et al. 2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R86\">Swinbank et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>Massive, dust-enshrouded and relatively evolved high-redshift galaxies are characterized by the bright thermal infrared emission from dust heated by intense star formation during their rapid primordial growth phase. These galaxies have typical stellar and dynamical masses of a few times <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>10&#8722;11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (<a name=\"InR79\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R79\">Smail et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R84\">Swinbank et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R63\">Nesvadba et al. 2007</a>) and form stars at prodigious rates of up to about <span class=\"simple-math\">1000 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>-1</sup></span>, which are unparallelled in the nearby Universe. As a population, dusty starburst galaxies may have contributed as much as about half of the total energy production from star formation at these cosmic epochs (e.g., <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R38\">Hauser &amp; Dwek 2001</a>; <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R23\">Dole et al. 2006</a>). </p>\n<p>Unfortunately, given their importance for our understanding of high-redshift star formation and galaxy growth, the high stellar and dynamical masses and short evolutionary timescales of these galaxies make them very rare on the sky. The densities of far-infrared (FIR) and submillimetre (sub-mm) selected galaxies that are bright enough to be good candidates for strong gravitational lensing are only around one every few square degrees for sources with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>500</sub> &#8776; 100 </span>mJy, with large uncertainties. For example, <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R50\">Lapi et al. (2012)</a> predict about 0.003&#8211;0.1 <span class=\"simple-math\">deg<sup>-2</sup></span> for sources with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>500</sub> &#8805; 400 </span>mJy on the sky, for expected maximum gravitational magnification factors of 20&#8211;30 adopted in the models. Consequently, we may expect to find only a few of these sources on the entire extragalactic sky, in accordance with models of the diffuse infrared background light (<a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R7\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2012</a>). Nonetheless, at luminosities above about <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>13</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (corresponding to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>500</sub> &#8776; 100 </span>mJy), they are expected to dominate the integrated FIR and sub-mm luminosity function (<a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R60\">Negrello et al. 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>A major breakthrough has been the recent discovery by <i>Herschel</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#FN7\">1</a></sup> and the South-Pole Telescope (SPT) of sizeable sets of strongly gravitationally lensed submillimetre galaxies, with typical magnification factors of a few. These are using the new generation of wide-field surveys (several thousand square degrees), probing in particular the range in FIR and sub-mm flux density between 100 and 200 mJy (e.g., <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R61\">Negrello et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R37\">Harris et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R89\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R92\">Wardlow et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R13\">Bussmann et al. 2013</a>). Most gravitationally lensed sources identified in these surveys are magnified by individual massive galaxies at intermediate redshifts, producing partial Einstein rings of a few arcsec in diameter and magnification factors up to about 10. However, the number of sources identified in these surveys above flux densities of 200&#8211;300 mJy remains rather small. For example, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R13\">Bussmann et al. (2013)</a> list 30 sources with FIR fluxes in this range, with six sources above <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> = 350 </span>mJy. So far, to our knowledge only one source with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub>&gt; 500 </span>mJy at 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m has been published by the SPT collaboration (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R89\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>). Meanwhile, the brightest source in the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R13\">Bussmann et al. (2013)</a> sample has <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> = 484 </span>mJy. </p>\n<p>The extragalactic <i>Herschel </i>and SPT surveys together cover about 4% of the sky, which highlights the importance of having an all-sky survey to identify high-redshift FIR and sub-mm galaxies above the 100&#8211;300 mJy regime in a systematic way. These sources are likely to be amongst the most strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies on the sky. <i>Planck </i>is the first all-sky survey in the submillimetre with the depth and spatial resolution necessary to probe the brightest, and presumably most strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift infrared galaxies observable to us. The 90% completeness limit of the <i>Planck </i>Catalogue of Compact Sources (PCCS) corresponds to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> &#8776; 6 &#215; 10<sup>13</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2</span> (<a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R69\">Planck Collaboration XXVIII 2014</a>). At these luminosities, even all-sky surveys may reveal only few sources (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R61\">Negrello et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R7\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R50\">Lapi et al. 2012</a>). For example, <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R39\">Herranz et al. (2013)</a> find only very few high-redshift sources in the Early Release Catalogue of Compact Sources (ERCSC) from <i>Planck </i>(Planck Collaboration VII 2011), primarily blazars. Most extragalactic sources in the ERCSC are low-redshift galaxies. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a><p>Near-infrared <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>-band images of the nine sources for which we already have optical/NIR imaging and millimetre interferometry (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F2\">2</a>). Contours show the <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>morphology at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>We used photometry derived from <i>Planck</i>-HFI (described in <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R67\">Planck Collaboration I 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R68\">Planck Collaboration VI 2014</a>) to identify all compact sources in the <i>Planck </i>maps that have colours consistent with being exceptionally bright, dusty, intensely star-forming high-redshift galaxies. We then obtained FIR photometry of the most promising candidates (the &#8220;HPASSS&#8221; programme, <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R70\">Planck Collaboration Int. XXVII 2015</a>, hereafter Paper I), using the Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver (SPIRE) on-board the <i>Herschel </i>space telescope. This sample, obtained through <i>Herschel </i>&#8220;Must-Do&#8221; Director&#8217;s Discretionary Time, includes 234 of the brightest, rarest sources in the sky (one source per several tens of square degrees, Planck Collaboration, in prep.). The sample was deliberately selected to only include sources that do not fall into the large <i>Herschel </i>survey fields, and which are new to the literature. SPIRE confirms that these sources have the typical sub-mm colours of high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> infrared and sub-mm galaxies. Most of the 234 sources of the HPASSS sample are overdensities of multiple galaxies with the typical FIR colours of high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies, and only four are Galactic cirrus clouds. Another small subset are bright individual, isolated point sources in the 20<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam of SPIRE, consistent with being exceptionally bright, presumably strongly gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies. An overview of the HPASSS sample is given in Paper I. </p>\n<p>\n        <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a><p>Mid-IR to millimetre photometry.</p>\n</div></div>\n      </p>\n<p>Here we present the first results of our multi-wavelength follow-up of the 11 brightest of these isolated HPASSS sources (&#8220;<i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS&#8221;), which can be observed from the northern hemisphere. All have flux densities at 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m measured with SPIRE that are at least <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> &#8776; 300 </span>mJy, well above the typical range probed by the SPT and wide-field <i>Herschel </i>surveys. The brightest source has <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> = 1050 </span>mJy. Welikala et al. (2015) discuss another set of weaker gravitational lenses observed with <i>Planck </i>and the SPT; however, the 11 sources we discuss here were previously unknown and are substantially brighter. Another source, PLCKERC857 PLCK_G270.59<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>58.52, taken from the ERCSC, which also satisfies our selection criteria and fortuitously falls into the H-ATLAS survey area, has already been discussed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R30\">Fu et al. (2012)</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R39\">Herranz et al. (2013)</a>, and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R13\">Bussmann et al. (2013)</a>. HLS 091828.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>514223 at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 5.2</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R72\">Rawle et al. 2014</a>) behind the galaxy cluster Abell 773, has been discovered independently from our survey as part of the <i>Herschel </i>Lensing Survey (<a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R26\">Egami et al. 2010</a>), but is also included in our <i>Planck </i>parent sample (Paper I). It forms a 1.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>, near-complete Einstein ring with a magnification factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">9 &#177; 2</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R72\">Rawle et al. 2014</a>). </p>\n<p>Our present analysis has three main goals. Firstly, we determine spectroscopic redshifts and provide empirical evidence from millimetre photometry and spectroscopy that these are indeed high-redshift sources, which owe their exceptional brightness in the submillimetre to strong gravitational lensing. We also show ground-based near-infrared (NIR) imaging, illustrating that the sub-mm sources lie behind overdense regions in the intermediate-redshift Universe. Secondly, we characterize their global dust and star-formation properties and show that their observed FIR emission is dominated by star formation, not by powerful obscured quasars. Thirdly, we estimate molecular gas masses from their CO line emission, calculate dust-to-gas mass ratios, and use their FIR luminosities and molecular gas mass estimates to show that they are more akin to very rapidly forming &#8220;starburst&#8221; galaxies, than the more gradually, but still intensely star-forming high-redshift galaxies on the &#8220;main sequence&#8221; (e.g., <a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R27\">Elbaz et al. 2011</a>). This is the first in a series of papers about &#8220;Planck&#8217;s Dusty GEMS&#8221;, and for this analysis we only use parts of the comprehensive data sets we already have in hand. Subsequent publications will provide lensing model solutions, discuss the spatially-resolved properties of our sources in a number of wavebands, and use the multiple millimetre line detections to investigate the detailed gas and star-formation properties of these systems. </p>\n<p>The outline of the paper is as follows. After the descriptions of our sample selection in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S2\">2</a>, and our follow-up observations and data reduction in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S3\">3</a>, we provide the redshifts in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S11\">4.2</a>, and the FIR luminosities, dust masses and temperatures in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S13\">5</a>. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S14\">6</a> we present the evidence that our sources are very strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies, including arcsec-resolution sub-mm and millimetre interferometry of the dust emission, as well as NIR/optical imaging. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S18\">7</a> we impose additional constraints from the <i>Wide</i>-field Infrared Survey Explorer, WISE and the VLA FIRST survey to demonstrate that the FIR spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of our sources are not dominated by radiation from powerful AGN, before turning to their gas and star-formation properties in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S22\">9</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S23\">10</a>, respectively. We summarize our results in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S24\">11</a>. Throughout the paper we adopt a flat <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70 km s<sup>-1</sup> Mpc<sup>-1</sup></span> concordance cosmology with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>M</sub> = 0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> = 0.7</span>. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Sample selection</h2>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F1\">1</a> we show 9 of our 11 newly discovered gravitational lens candidates, which are the brightest amongst our sources selected from the nominal data release of the <i>Planck </i>all-sky survey. The parent sample consists of two subsets that were identified with similar colour cuts in the 857-GHz to 545-GHz flux density ratio of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>857</sub>/<i>S</i><sub>545</sub> &lt; 1.5</span>&#8211;2. This is well-matched to the expected spectral shape of the FIR continuum of dusty starburst galaxies at redshifts <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 2</span>. Six of our sources were taken from the PCCS, which includes all sources with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&gt; 4</span> at 545 GHz on the cleanest 52% of the sky (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R69\">Planck Collaboration XXVIII 2014</a>). Five sources come from a dedicated, blind search for high-redshift candidates in the <i>Planck </i>maps, which probes fainter sources in the cleanest 35% of the sky after subtracting estimates of the cosmic microwave background and Galactic cirrus emission. Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a> lists the origin of each target. The second subsample will be described in detail by Planck Collaboration (in prep.). A comprehensive summary of the selection and in particular the cleaning algorithm adopted to identify this subsample is given in Paper I. </p>\n<p>All sources were followed up with <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>photometry at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m as part of the HPASSS survey, mostly during &#8220;Must-Do&#8221; Director&#8217;s Discretionary Time, and is a subset of the sample presented in Paper I. SPIRE has about 10 times greater depth and 20 times higher spatial resolution than <i>Planck</i>, with beam FWHMs of 18<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>, 24<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>, and 35<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, respectively<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#FN8\">2</a></sup>. Therefore, SPIRE can be used to identify and localize the counterparts of <i>Planck </i>sources in the same wavelength regime. We identified all potential gravitationally lensed galaxies as bright, isolated point sources in the SPIRE images, with SEDs peaking at flux densities above 300 mJy in either the 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m or the 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m band as observed with SPIRE (in the final calibration of our SPIRE maps, one source has <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> = 294 </span>mJy). This is well matched to the 90% completeness limit of the PCCS of about 600 mJy (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R69\">Planck Collaboration XXVIII 2014</a>), and purposefully excludes similar sources already identified in other surveys. </p>\n<p>We find a total of 15 gravitational lens candidates. For the purposes of this paper, we exclude the two already described in the literature (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R30\">Fu et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>, see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S1\">1</a>), and another two that are in the far South. The source described by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. (2012)</a> is at a higher redshift (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 5.2</span>) than the sources we discuss here. Apart from that, including those other sources would not change our general conclusions. </p>\n<p>In the present analysis we discuss the 11 Northern sources that are already spectroscopically confirmed to be at high redshifts. It is worth noting that by focusing on single, very bright sources in the <i>Herschel </i>images, we may have missed sets of multiple, but fainter gravitationally lensed objects behind the same intervening structures; these we would have identified as overdensities of high-redshift infrared galaxies in the overall HPASSS sample (Paper I). Irrespective of this, given the extraordinary sky coverage of our parent sample and the brightness of our targets, six of which reach or even exceed the completeness limits of the PCCS in the 353, 545, and 857 GHz bands of 330, 570, and 680 mJy, respectively (Table 1 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R69\">Planck Collaboration XXVIII 2014</a>), the 11 sources discussed here are likely to be amongst the brightest individual high-redshift galaxies on the sky. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>3. Photometry</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>3.1. <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>FIR photometry</h3>\n<p>We base our analysis on the <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>photometry at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, as well as on ground-based JCMT/SCUBA-2 850-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and IRAM/GISMO 2-mm single-dish photometry. For sources in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.2</span>&#8211;3.6, this corresponds to a wavelength range 50&#8211;80 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 400&#8211;600 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame, which cover the expected peak and Rayleigh-Jeans tail, respectively, of the warm dust emission heated by intense star formation. </p>\n<p><i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>observations were carried out between December 2012 and March 2013. The <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>photometry was obtained using <tt>STARFINDER </tt>(<a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R22\">Diolaiti et al. 2000</a>) as part of the HPASSS survey, and is discussed in detail in Paper I. <tt>STARFINDER </tt>integrates over the point spread function obtained directly from the image, and is therefore more suitable for data dominated by confusion noise than classical aperture photometry. Measured flux densities are between 294 mJy and 1054 mJy at 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and between 270 mJy and 800 mJy at 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, respectively (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a>). Typical uncertainties are of the order of 5&#8211;10 mJy, which is close to the confusion level in the maps (<a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R64\">Nguyen et al. 2010</a>), but only includes the measurement error, not the systematic uncertainty of 7% inherent in the SPIRE photometry. However, this has no impact on our results. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3.2. JCMT/SCUBA-2 photometry at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m</h3>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p>Near-infrared <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>-band images of the nine sources from Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F1\">1</a>. Contours show the SMA morphology at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m. The FWHM beam size of all SMA data is about 2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> (the FWHM beam size is shown in the bottom left corner of each panel), except for PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8, where it is 0.8<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The SCUBA-2 (<a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R40\">Holland et al. 2013</a>) data were taken between September 2012 and May 2014 in moderate conditions with individual observing times of 15 min per source. The data were reduced using a configuration file optimized for point-source calibrators using the <tt>smurf </tt>data reduction software package for SCUBA-2 (<a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R14\">Chapin et al. 2013</a>). Flux densities were extracted using aperture photometry with a 30<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> diameter aperture, where the background was estimated within an annulus with inner and outer diameters of 37.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> and 60<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>, respectively. Uncertainties are between 4 mJy and 21 mJy per beam. These flux densities are then corrected for missing flux density due to the aperture size by dividing by 0.85, as described by <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R21\">Dempsey et al. (2013)</a>. An 8% calibration uncertainty is added in quadrature to the photometric errors. The resulting 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m flux densities are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.3. SMA 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m interferometry</h3>\n<p>All sources were also observed in the continuum with the SMA in the 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m band. Observations were carried out between June 2013 and June 2014. Data were taken under good to excellent conditions with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>pwv</i>&lt; 2 </span>mm in shared-track mode to obtain good <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>uv</i></span> coverage, in spite of observing each source with less than one track; this was made possible by their extraordinary brightness in the submillimetre. Integration times per source are between 2 and 7 h. All sources but PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8 were observed through programme 2013B-S050 in the compact configuration, with a beam of about <span class=\"simple-math\">2&#8243; &#215; 2&#8243;</span>. PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8 was observed through DDT programme 2013A-S075 in the extended configuration, giving a beam of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.8&#8243; &#215; 0.5&#8243;</span>. Data were calibrated in IDL using the <tt>MIR </tt>package, and analysis and imaging utilized the <tt>MIRIAD </tt>package. A full discussion of the interferometry is beyond the scope of the present analysis, and will be presented in a subsequent publication. Here we only use the 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m morphologies to illustrate that these are indeed strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies. Comparison with the single-dish flux densities from SCUBA-2 suggests that we recover at least 80&#8211;90% of the total flux density, implying that we have typically not missed fainter, more extended components. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.4. IRAM-30-m /GISMO 2-mm photometry</h3>\n<p>Two-mm continuum observations were carried out with the 30-m telescope of IRAM between 17 and 23 April with 1.3&#8211;1.7 mm of precipitable water vapour, and between 29 October and 5 November 2013, with 3.4&#8211;8.6 mm of preciptable water vapour (programmes 222-12 and 100-13). </p>\n<p>We used the <span class=\"simple-math\">8 &#215; 16</span> pixel bolometer camera GISMO, which covers a frequency range of 140&#8211;162 GHz (<a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R83\">Staguhn et al. 2012</a>) in the 2-mm band. At the 30-m telescope of IRAM, GISMO covers a <span class=\"simple-math\">1.8&#8242; &#215; 3.7&#8242;</span> field of view with a <span class=\"simple-math\">21&#8243; &#215; 21&#8243;</span> beam. We used <span class=\"simple-math\">2&#8242; &#215; 2&#8242;</span> Lissajous maps with a relative flux density stability of about 8%, which is optimized to obtain high signal-to-noise ratios of relatively faint objects like ours, with only a small number of bad channels. Total integration times per source were between 10 and 100 min, depending on the expected flux density of the target. </p>\n<p>We used the <tt>CRUSH </tt>software package (<a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R46\">Kovacs 2013</a>) to reduce and calibrate individual scans, and to combine them into the final image. We used the &#8220;faint&#8221; option, which is well adapted to signals around 10 mJy, detected at signal-to-noise ratios of less than 10 per scan. We detected all targets as point sources, with S/N between 3.4 and 14.8. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.5. CFHT and VLT optical/NIR photometry</h3>\n<p>In order to identify and broadly characterize the foreground lensing structure, we also obtained NIR optical imaging of our sample using Megacam and WIRCAM on the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT), and with HAWKI and FORS on the Very Large Telescope (VLT) of the European Southern Observatory (ESO). Here we use the optical imaging to highlight that our sources lie behind massive intervening structures, either galaxy groups or clusters. Observations of the overall sample are still on-going, but have already provided us with optical or NIR imaging of all but one target in at least one band. We used the <tt>scamp </tt>and <tt>swarp </tt>software (<a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R5\">Bertin 2010a</a>,<a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R6\">b</a>) to register our images relative to the USNO-B2 catalog, with a typical positional uncertainty of 0.2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>0.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>. A full discussion of these data and what they imply more quantitatively for the lensing configuration will be presented in a subsequent publication. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>4. Blind spectroscopic redshift survey  in the millimetre</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>4.1. IRAM 30 m/EMIR spectroscopy</h3>\n<p>We performed a blind redshift search in the 3-mm and 2-mm bands for all 11 targets using the wide-band heterodyne receiver EMIR at the 30-m telescope of IRAM. Following a pilot programme to measure a spectroscopic redshift of our first source, PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8, through regular programme 82-12 and Director&#8217;s Discretionary programme D05-12, we obtained another 75 h of observing time through Director&#8217;s Discretionary programme D09-12 and the regular programme 094-13 in April and June 2013. For all sources we used the WILMA and FTS backends during good to variable conditions. </p>\n<p>Individual scans were 30 s long, and we observed sets of 12 scans followed by a calibration. Data were reduced using <tt>CLASS </tt>(<a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R33\">Gildas Team 2013</a>). We took advantage of a dedicated routine kindly provided by C. Kramer to individually correct the baselines in each of the sub-bands of the FTS backend. The full set of lines will be discussed in a subsequent publication; here we only use the lowest-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> CO transition available in each source, which provides additional empirical evidence that these are strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies. The redshifts are also derived from these lines, and found to be consistent with the full set of available lines per galaxy. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>4.2. Spectroscopic redshifts</h3>\n<p>To obtain a spectroscopic redshift for each source, we started with a blind line search in the 3-mm atmospheric window, which we cover almost entirely with two interleaved tunings of EMIR centred at 89.4 GHz and 97.4 GHz, respectively. We used the WILMA and FTS backends in parallel, which have band widths of about 4 GHz and 8 GHz, respectively. </p>\n<p>We discovered a bright emission line in each source in one of the tunings in the 3-mm band (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F3\">3</a>). Subsequently we calculated all possible redshifts compatible with the observed frequency of the line, and tested our redshift hypothesis by searching for a second line (typically CO(5&#8211;4) or CO(4&#8211;3)) at the predicted higher frequency. This required a separate frequency tuning, with the choice depending on each redshift hypothesis (typically lying in the 2-mm band). We started with the redshift that was closest to the photometric redshift derived from our SPIRE photometry, assuming a dust temperature of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>d</sub> = 30 </span>K, which is the temperature of the dust component that dominates the FIR SED of the Cosmic Eyelash (<a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R42\">Ivison et al. 2010b</a>). This yielded the correct redshift in all but the two galaxies, specifically those with the highest dust temperatures (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>). In the end, our EMIR follow-up spectroscopy led to accurate and secure spectroscopic redshifts for all 11 targets, with 2&#8211;8 lines detected per source; this provides a wide range of constraints on the physical properties of the gas in these galaxies, which we will discuss in more detail in forthcoming papers. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p>Lowest-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> CO emission line in each of our targets. CO(3&#8211;2) and CO(4&#8211;3) are indicated in yellow and green, respectively. Red dotted lines show simple single-Gaussian fits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a><p>Fitted parameters to the FIR dust continuum and dust properties.</p>\n</div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3</span></a><p>CO line properties obtained with EMIR on the IRAM 30-m telescope.</p>\n</div></div>\n        </p>\n<p><i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS fall in the redshift range of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.2</span>&#8211;3.6, comparable to that of radio-selected submillimetre galaxies in the field (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R15\">Chapman et al. 2005</a>), and very similar to that of gravitationally lensed sub-mm galaxies in the H-ATLAS survey (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.1&#8722;3.5</span>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R37\">Harris et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R13\">Bussmann et al. 2013</a>). The average redshift of <i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.9 &#177; 0.4</span> (we give the width of the distribution here), is somewhat lower than the redshift range of the bright gravitationally lensed sub-mm galaxies from the SPT survey. The SPT sample has a mean redshift of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.5</span>, obtained from at least two lines for 12 of their 26 targets, and a combination of single-line detections and FIR photometric constraints for the remaining targets (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R89\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R93\">Wei&#223; et al. 2013</a>). One reason that we probe somewhat lower redshifts may be that we select our sources at shorter wavelengths (350&#8211;850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, compared to 1.4 and 2.0 mm for the SPT). However, we stress that our parent sample from <i>Planck </i>does include sources with higher redshifts, such as HLS 091828.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>514223 at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 5.2</span> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R72\">Rawle et al. 2014</a>), a source we selected independently from its confirmation as a high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> source through the HLS survey. We also note that the <i>Planck </i>selection is based on 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, 550 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m measurements, covering somewhat longer wavelengths than the blind <i>Herschel </i>surveys. The <i>Planck </i>high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> sample has a range of FIR colours, and the redshift distribution derived from the subsample of very bright gravitational lenses does not necessarily correspond to the redshift distribution of the overall <i>Planck </i>high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> sample (HLS 091828.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>514223 at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 5.2</span> being a case in point). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.3. Line profiles and luminosities</h3>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F3\">3</a> shows the lines we detected in the 3-mm band. Many sources exhibit complex line profiles, which can also be seen in the higher frequency data (Canameras et al., in prep.). These may either originate from several, gravitationally lensed regions in the same galaxy that are blended in the large (20<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>) beam of the IRAM 30-m telescope, or else they represent sets of nearby, perhaps interacting galaxies. Alternatively, they may represent intrinsically complex gas kinematics in single star-forming environments, driven by the interplay of galaxy rotation, feedback, or perhaps turbulent motion within star-forming regions. High-resolution follow-up interferometry is currently being analysed to further elucidate their nature. </p>\n<p>We fitted the emission lines shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F3\">3</a> with single Gaussian profiles to obtain the line FWHMs and integrated fluxes listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T3\">3</a>. Integrated fluxes are <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>I</i><sub>CO</sub> = (7&#8722;34) Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>, for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>FWHM</i> = 213</span>&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\">685 km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. A detailed analysis of the spectral properties of our sources that uses all our full sets of spectral line observations and that takes into account changes in line ratios in individual, kinematically distinct emission line regions into account will be presented elsewhere. Here we only use the spectroscopic redshifts, and the fluxes and FWHM line widths of the lowest-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>CO transition observed in each source in order to demonstrate that these are indeed gravitationally lensed galaxies with extreme magnification factors. </p>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T3\">3</a> we also compile luminosity estimates for the CO lines that we detect. We follow <a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R81\">Solomon et al. (1997)</a> in translating the integrated line fluxes into CO luminosities (in brightness temperature units), setting <a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-eq77.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>Here the measured frequency <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#957;</i></span> is given in GHz, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> is the redshift, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub><i>L</i></sub></span> is the luminosity distance, the CO luminosity <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;</span> is measured in <span class=\"simple-math\">K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup></span>, and the integrated CO line flux is in <span class=\"simple-math\">Jy km s<sup>-1</sup></span>. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S22\">9</a> we will also derive molecular gas mass estimates and compare with the dust masses obtained from our SED fitting. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>5. Dust properties</h2>\n<p>To further characterize our sources, we fitted their FIR-to-millimetre photometry with modified blackbody distributions between 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 2000 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, using the Python <tt>curve_fit </tt>routine from the scipy package<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#FN9\">3</a></sup>. The results are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F4\">4</a>. Most photometry points were observed with roughly similar beam sizes between 15<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> and 30<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>, and we only see single, very bright components in each image, which makes us confident that uncertainties related to confusion and multiple sources within the same beam do not dominate our photometry. We do see the foreground lensing sources at short wavelengths, between the optical and NIR, including the blue channels of WISE. However, their relatively blue colours and locations suggest that they do not contribute significantly to the long-wavelength emission. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p>Modified blackbody fits to the FIR-to-millimetre photometry of our sources as obtained with <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>at 250, 350, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, with JCMT/SCUBA-2 at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m (for eight sources), and with IRAM/Gismo at 2 mm. The light and dark blue curves show the blackbody curves for optically thin and optically thick dust, respectively. Error bars are printed in black, and are smaller than the symbols showing the photometric data points.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>In the restframe of our targets, our data cover the peak of the SED and extend well into the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of the dust emission, which is a particularly clean probe of the thermal emission of the coldest dust component, dominating the overall mass budget. We followed, e.g., <a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R8\">Blain et al. (2003)</a> to allow for a frequency-dependent optical depth of the FIR emission, which we model in the standard way through a power law with emissivity index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = 2.0</span> and a critical wavelength of 100 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, at which the dust opacity becomes unity. This specific choice of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> is somewhat arbitrary, but at the signal-to-noise ratio and sparse frequency sampling of our SEDs, the precise value has a minor impact (for plausible values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i></span> between 1.5 and 2.0) for our study. For example, we find typical offsets in dust temperature <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<i>T</i><sub>d</sub> &#8776; 2 </span>K between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = 1.5</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = 2.0</span>, comparable to our other uncertainties. </p>\n<p>These fits correspond to dust temperatures of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>d</sub> = 33</span>&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\">50 </span>K, with no significant trend with redshift (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>). Uncertainties were derived from Monte Carlo simulations, where we varied the measured flux density in each band 1000 times within the measurement uncertainties, before fitting the SED in the same way as for the data. </p>\n<p>The high infrared luminosities and dust temperatures of <i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS suggest that most of the radiation in our sources comes from dense star-forming clouds, which is why we consider the optically thick case more relevant to our analysis. We note, however, that had we fit for optically thin emission, we would have derived temperatures between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>d</sub> = 30 </span>K and 41 K, lower by 3 K to 11 K in each individual source. Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F4\">4</a> shows that all sources are adequately fit with a single temperature component, in spite of a slight, systematic underestimate of the 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, or alternatively, slight overestimate of the 500-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m flux density. </p>\n<p>The temperature range we find does not differ significantly from those of other strongly lensed samples of high-redshift dusty star-forming galaxies selected in the FIR and (sub-)mm. This is illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F5\">5</a>. It is interesting that the temperature range of our sources includes those of typical starburst galaxies at high redshift, as well as the lower temperatures of more gradually, but still intensely, star-forming galaxies along the main sequence (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R27\">Elbaz et al. 2011</a>). We do not find an obvious trend of dust temperature with redshift. This may either be due to the small number of targets observed over a relatively small redshift range, or because we are sampling environments with a range of properties within individual galaxies. </p>\n<p>We derive infrared luminosities by integrating over our best-fit single-component modified blackbody SEDs between 8 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 1000 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame, using the flux densities given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a> and dust temperatures in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>. Luminosities thus obtained are in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub> = (4.6&#8722;26.5) &#215; 10<sup>13</sup><i>&#956;</i><sup>-1</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>, including the unknown gravitational magnification factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>. Following <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R45\">Kennicutt (1998)</a> we set <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i> [ <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>-1</sup> ]</span><span class=\"simple-math\">= 4.5 &#215; 10<sup>-37</sup><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> [W], finding star-formation rates <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>SFR</i> = 8000</span>&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\">46 000 <i>&#956;</i><sup>-1</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>-1</sup></span>, suggesting high intrinsic star-formation rates and high magnification factors. Corresponding apparent dust masses are <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>d</sub> = (3.5&#8722;11) &#215; 10<sup>9</sup><i>&#956;</i><sup>-1</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>). </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F4\">4</a> shows that we cover the peak of the dust SED for most sources, but nonetheless our sensitivity to warmer dust components probed in the FIR shortwards of 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m (60&#8211;80 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame) is limited, and we are likely to miss emission from warmer dust components. Through template fitting with <tt>DecompIR </tt>(<a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R57\">Mullaney et al. 2011</a>), which we will further discuss in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S18\">7</a>, we derived fiducial correction factors between the modified blackbody fits obtained here, and the templates we used to accommodate our FIR-to-submillimetre photometry (and constraints from WISE at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m within the same SED fit). We thus find that our modified blackbody fits may underestimate the IR luminosity of our targets by 10&#8211;30%. We also list the respective values obtained from <tt>DecompIR </tt>in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>. Taken together, the direct estimate from the modified blackbody fits, and those from the templates, set a plausible range of luminosities. These luminosities would need to be corrected towards larger values if an additional warmer dust component was found with infrared constraints shortward of 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m. </p>\n<p>We follow, e.g., <a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. (2012)</a> in estimating dust masses, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>d</sub></span>, by setting <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-eq95.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub><i>L</i></sub></span> is the luminosity distance to redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub><i>&#957;</i><sub>0</sub></sub></span> the flux density at the observed frequency <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#957;</i><sub>r</sub>(1 + <i>z</i>)<sup>-1</sup></span>, which we set to 600 GHz (corresponding to the 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m band of <tt>SPIRE</tt>). <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>CMB</sub></span> is the CMB temperature at redshift <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span>. We used <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-eq100.png\"></span>, with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = 2.0</span> as already stated above. With this approach and these assumptions, we find dust masses of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>d</sub> = (3.5&#8722;11) &#215; 10<sup>9</sup><i>&#956;</i><sup>-1</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span>, with the unknown gravitational magnification factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>. Results for individual sources are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>6. Signatures of gravitational lensing</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>6.1. Flux densities and morphologies</h3>\n<p>The first observational hint that our targets might indeed be strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies is their sheer brightness and small angular size below 18<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> (the FWHM of the SPIRE point spread function at the highest frequency, 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m), whereas 90% of the 234 Planck high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> candidates with <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>follow-up consist of multiple sources. Unlensed high-redshift galaxies with FIR flux densities as high as those of our sources are very rare. For example, for flux densities <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub>&gt; 400 </span>mJy at 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and near the peak of the FIR SEDs of most GEMS, the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R7\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2012)</a> models predict 3 sources sr<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8805; 2</span> that are not, and 53 sources sr<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> that are gravitationally lensed. For a given source at these flux densities, it is therefore much more likely to find a gravitationally lensed galaxy than a galaxy in the field. We emphasize that this is true only for galaxies with confirmed high redshifts like the GEMS. The overall population of bright FIR galaxies is at much lower redshifts and has bluer FIR colours. </p>\n<p>Given that more typical high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies in the field have FIR flux densities of few 10s mJy, the observed flux densities of our sources make us expect magnification factors of at least a few and perhaps greater than 10, even if these were intrinsically amongst the most luminous sources on the sky. For more moderate, more typical intrinsic flux densities, the gravitational magnification would be accordingly higher. The one alternative interpretation could be that these are multiple, highly concentrated galaxies within projected distances of a few tens of kpc, so that they are not resolved into individual galaxies by the SPIRE beam, which corresponds to about 120 kpc at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8776; 2</span> (for an example see <a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R43\">Ivison et al. 2013</a>). </p>\n<p>More direct evidence that our sources indeed have a lensing nature comes from their morphologies. Strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies may either be single or multiple compact images seen near the intervening foreground lensing source, giant arcs extending over several arcseconds, or even partial or complete Einstein rings. However, reaching the required spatial resolutions of about 1&#8211;2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> or better requires either deep optical or NIR imaging for sources that are not too heavily obscured, or, alternatively, sub-mm or millimetre interferometry. </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F1\">1</a> shows the <i>Herschel </i>image as contours overlaid on optical imaging, and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F2\">2</a> the dust morphology obtained with the SMA at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m. These figures clearly show that our sources are either single, compact objects at 2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> resolution (as is the case for, e.g., PLCK_G244.8<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>54.9 and PLCK_G138.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>62.0), or giant arcs (e.g., PLCK_G145.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>50.9 and PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8). PLCK_G244.8<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>54.9 and PLCK_G138.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>62.0 have flux densities of 1054 <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span> 10 and 664 <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span>8 mJy, respectively, making it implausible that these are individual high-redshift galaxies if not benefitting from a strong boost from gravitational lensing through a massive foreground source. At a 2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam, intrinsic source sizes of unlensed galaxies would be at most 16 kpc, making it implausible to see a small group of high-redshift galaxies within a single beam. </p>\n<p>Our sources are associated with overdensities of massive intervening galaxies at intermediate redshift, either galaxy groups or clusters. Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a> lists the redshifts of the brightest intervening galaxies along the line of sight to our targets, which were taken from the SDSS. They are either photometric redshifts or (in a few individual cases highlighted in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a>), spectroscopic redshifts. A detailed analysis of the lensing structure based on our own proprietary optical/NIR photometry obtained at the CFHT and the VLT is on-going. The only target associated with a foreground object for which we currently have no good redshift estimate is G145.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>50.9, which forms a near-complete Einstein ring with a diameter of 10<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> around a very red foreground source, which we currently only detect in the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>-band. For this galaxy, our optical/NIR photometry is not yet complete, and we must therefore defer a detailed analysis of the foreground source to a later publication. </p>\n<p>In the rest of this section we will present additional empirical evidence to illustrate that all of our sample consists of strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies, including those for which we do not yet have morphological constraints. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p>Characterizing our sources by their FIR luminosities, dust temperatures, and redshifts. <i>Top</i>: FIR luminosities versus dust temperatures. The Dusty GEMS targets are shown as red stars on top of the comparison samples of strongly lensed sources taken from the literature (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. 2012</a>, and references therein), lens candidates from the SPT survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R89\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>), the Eyelash (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R42\">Ivison et al. 2010b</a>), and the two <i>Planck </i>lenses that were discovered prior to our work (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R30\">Fu et al. 2012</a>). The solid line shows a fit to the general population, while the dotted lines show magnification factors of 10 and 50. <i>Bottom</i>: FIR luminosity as a function of redshift. In the lower panel, our sources fall near the most luminous gravitationally lensed galaxies at similar redshifts; however, these are strongly dominated by AGN, like APM 08279<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>5255, whereas our sources are bona fide starbursts, at least in the image plane. This explains the greater luminosities at lower dust temperatures seen in the top panel.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>6.2. FIR dust continuum</h3>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. (2012)</a> suggested the use of the relationship between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>d</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> as an empirical indicator of whether a source is strongly gravitationally lensed. According to the Stefan-Boltzmann law, the luminosity emitted by a modified blackbody at a given temperature depends only on the size of the emitting surface and the emissivity.
