Therefore, if our galaxies form a subset of the generic population of dusty, intensely star-forming high-redshift galaxies, the gravitational magnification factor should lead to an apparent increase in dust luminosity at a given temperature for gravitationally lensed galaxies, compared to unlensed galaxies. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F5\">5</a> we show where our sources fall on a plot of dust temperature versus FIR luminosity, compared to the galaxies of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. (2012)</a> and other sources from the literature. It is immediately clear that our sources are significantly brighter at a given temperature than galaxies in the field, and even brighter than most of the previously known gravitationally lensed galaxies. The dashed lines illustrate luminosities that are 10 times and 50 times brighter than expected from a simple least square fit to the population of field galaxies (green solid line). We highlight the Cosmic Eyelash of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R85\">Swinbank et al. (2010)</a> and the two previously confirmed gravitationally lensed galaxies with <i>Planck </i>counterparts (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R30\">Fu et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>For a more explicit, although not necessarily very precise estimate that exploits this relationship between dust temperature, luminosity, and source size, we can use the Stefan-Boltzmann law directly to infer the magnification factor from the observed luminosity and dust temperature. The approach is described in detail in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. (2012)</a>. Given the somewhat higher dust temperatures of our lens candidates compared to the SPT sources of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. (2012)</a>, we have a larger range of &#8220;effective&#8221; Stefan-Boltzmann constants (which correct for the lower emissivity of a modified relative to a genuine blackbody), <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>eff</sub>/<i>&#963;</i> = 0.5</span>&#8211;0.65, and apparent emitting surfaces that are between 8 and 40 times larger than those of typical FIR galaxies, implying magnification factors that are roughly similar. These results are also shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F6\">6</a>. We note that the estimates are very uncertain, since they assume that each high-redshift galaxy has a similar emissivity, that the dust becomes optically thick at similar wavelengths, and that the interstellar medium (ISM) of the galaxies is dominated by a uniform dust component with a single temperature. Each of these assumptions can only be approximately true, and this will lead to uncertainties of at least factors of a few in this estimate. This is illustrated by the magnification factor of about 10 of the &#8220;Cosmic Eyelash,&#8221; which we constrained with the same approach, and which falls into a very similar region of the diagram as our sources. The &#8220;Cosmic Eyelash&#8221; has intrinsic magnification factors of 20<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>60 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R86\">Swinbank et al. 2011</a>), with an average factor of 32.5. In spite of these caveats, Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F5\">5</a> provides additional indirect support that our sources are indeed strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>6.3. Molecular gas lines</h3>\n<p>More empirical evidence for strong gravitational magnification of our galaxies comes from the emission-line properties that we measured with EMIR on the IRAM 30-m telescope. To demonstrate that their galaxies discovered through the H-ATLAS survey are indeed strongly gravitationally lensed, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R37\">Harris et al. (2012)</a> compared the CO(1&#8211;0) line luminosities <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;</span> and FWHMs of their galaxies with the sources of <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R9\">Bothwell et al. (2013)</a>, who had found a broad trend between luminosity and line width in galaxies in the field (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F6\">6</a>). The galaxies of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R37\">Harris et al. (2012)</a> and other strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies from the literature stand out by 1&#8211;2 orders of magnitude above this relationship, owing to the boost in line luminosity by the gravitational lens. In contrast, lines are expected to be as broad as in field galaxies (or narrower, because smaller regions of the large-scale velocity field of the galaxy are being observed). If a small region in a galaxy is magnified by strong gravitational lensing, then only parts of the rotation curve will be sampled, and turbulent motion will also be smaller. Therefore, observed line widths should be narrower than if galaxy-wide radii are probed, as in field galaxies. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p><i>Top</i>: order-of-magnitude estimate of the gravitational magnification factor derived from the dust temperature and FIR luminosity of our sources compared to FIR and sub-mm galaxies in the field (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S16\">6.2</a> for details). <i>Bottom</i>: CO emission-line luminosity as a function of FWHM line width, using the same symbols as in the top panel, with additional light blue dots showing those sources of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R9\">Bothwell et al. (2013)</a>, which are neither gravitationally lensed nor AGN hosts. The solid and dashed lines show the best linear fit to the sample of field galaxies, as well as shifts of this line corresponding to magnification factors of 5, 10, and 20. Error bars show the 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainties of our single-component Gaussian line fits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F6\">6</a>, inspired by Fig. 7 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R37\">Harris et al. (2012)</a>, shows where our sources fall relative to the Harris et al. sample and those in the literature. Our sources span a large range in FWHM in this diagram, but are all clearly within the regime of gravitationally lensed galaxies. The FWHMs of some of our targets may be as large as those of overdensities of multiple lensed sources that are at best moderately gravitationally lensed like the example in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R43\">Ivison et al. (2013)</a>. Their luminosities are factors of a few brighter, placing them firmly above the field galaxies, and into the lens regime. The example of the Cosmic Eyelash, which has a magnification factor of 20&#8211;60 shows however that the lensing factor derived from the position of a source in this diagram can only be an approximate indicator. The line luminosities and profiles provide additional evidence in support for the lensing hypothesis. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>7. Dust heating and AGN content</h2>\n<p>Many dusty high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> starburst galaxies host powerful AGN. For example <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R1\">Alexander et al. (2005)</a> find that 75% of submillimetre galaxies have AGN detected at X-ray wavelengths (but see also <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R49\">Laird et al. 2010</a>,who find significantly lower fractions of 10&#8211;20%). Powerful, obscured AGN could contribute significantly to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span>, which would lower the magnification factors that are needed to explain the extraordinary apparent brightness of our targets. The inferred dust temperatures of our sources are akin to those of other high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> starburst galaxies and would be very low compared to those of obscured quasars, which are typically above 70 K, often far above. However, our estimates may be biased towards low temperatures because of the absence of mid-IR constraints shortward of 50&#8211;80 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in our data sets. This makes it worthwhile to investigate in more depth what the possible AGN contribution might be to the infrared luminosity budget of our targets. </p>\n<p>Not all AGN play a significant role for the total infrared luminosity budget of their host galaxies. Ideally, searching for obscured AGN activity in our targets would require PACS or at least deep <i>Spitzer</i> 24-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m photometry, to sample the dust SED shortward of about 100 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame. Since our sample was only discovered with SPIRE in the last weeks of the <i>Herschel </i>mission, such data sets are not available. Additionally, in spite of their exceptional brightness (for high-redshift targets), they are still too faint to obtain robust mid-IR photometric constraints with SOFIA. We might therefore not be able to give tight constraints on the presence of weak AGN activity in all of our sources, however, most important for our purposes here is to show that AGN radiation is not energetically dominant in our sources (i.e., they do not contribute <span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>0.5 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>bol</sub></span>), which would have important implications for the estimated star formation rates, plausible ranges of intrinsic infrared luminosities, and gas excitation. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>7.1. WISE 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m photometry</h3>\n<p>WISE in the 22-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m band covers rest-frame wavelengths between 4 and 7 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m for our sources, i.e., the far blue tail of hot dust emission from powerful AGN. Consequently, WISE has been successfully used to identify heavily obscured AGN at high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> (e.g., <a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R94\">Yan et al. 2013</a>). All of our sources are bright enough to be detected in WISE imaging at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and seven are included in the WISE catalogues. The remaining four can be seen as very faint sources in the WISE images, but are not bright enough to obtain robust flux measurements. We will in the following use the flux measurements from the WISE catalogs and treat the 5<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> rms of this catalog at 5.4 mJy as upper limit for the fainter sources. Individual flux densities are listed for all sources in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a>. </p>\n<p>Although we do detect nearby bluer sources in each case at 3.4 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, 4.6 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and 12 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, the SED in all but one source falls off too steeply in the three blue WISE bands to contribute significantly to the 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m detections. Their colours suggest that these are low-to-intermediate-redshift objects, which we consider part of the intervening lensing structure. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S20\"></a>7.2. Constraining AGN dust heating with <tt>DecompIR</tt>\n</h3>\n<p>We used the publicly available package <tt>DecompIR </tt>(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R57\">Mullaney et al. 2011</a>) to constrain the potential contribution from AGN emission to the infrared SED, using our six available data points between 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 2 mm, as listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T1\">1</a>. <tt>DecompIR </tt>performs <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> fits to infrared SEDs using composites of empirically constructed templates of starburst galaxies and AGN. We only have six photometric data points, but we sample the Rayleigh-Jeans tail and the peak of the SED of the emission from the coldest dust component, and therefore constrain the most abundant dust component well. We have spectroscopic redshifts and hence can estimate robust dust temperatures, and therefore we consider this part of the SED to be well constrained. Our main uncertainties are blueward of the dust peak, which we only sample with the 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m data point from WISE and the 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m data point from SPIRE. The 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m band corresponds to 50&#8211;80 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame for our targets, is slightly blueward of the peak of the dust emission in most of our sources (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F4\">4</a>), and falls near the expected peak of the infrared emission from hot dust in the AGN torus in most templates (e.g., <a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R71\">Polletta et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R62\">Nenkova et al. 2008</a>). The SEDs of powerful AGN host galaxies at high redshifts are typically dominated by AGN emission at these wavelengths (e.g., <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R74\">Sajina et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R25\">Drouart et al. 2014</a>). </p>\n<p>The <tt>DecompIR </tt>software package provides a small set of SED templates, derived from nearby starburst galaxies. One complication in using these templates for our sources is that we find a range of dust temperatures, which are not all well represented by existing templates. This would lead to considerable (but somewhat artificial) discrepancies in the template fitting that would be hard to overcome without a self-consistent model of the mid-to-far-IR SED of high-redshift galaxies, which does not yet exist. To avoid such mismatches, while make optimal use of our existing constraints without overinterpreting the mid-IR data, we therefore constructed a simple starburst template for each of our galaxies from the &#8220;SB2&#8221; template of <tt>DecompIR </tt>(corresponding to the SED of NGC 7252, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R57\">Mullaney et al. 2011</a>), but correcting for the mismatch in dust temperatures. We therefore fitted and removed from the template the modified blackbody contribution from cold dust in the FIR. The residual is a template of the SED in the mid-IR only, to which we added the modified blackbody emission obtained from our FIR fits, using the measured temperature for each source. We selected this particular template, because it provided the best match to the FIR and sub-millimetre measurements of the dust peak and Rayleigh-Jeans tail, with no regard of the goodness of fit of the 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m observations. For the AGN component, we simply used the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R71\">Polletta et al. (2007)</a> type-2 QSO template which is already part of <tt>DecompIR</tt>. </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F7\">7</a> shows that we can rule out a bolometrically dominant AGN contribution from buried quasars, in all cases. Only three galaxies have best-fit results formally inconsistent with pure starbursts. In PLCK_G092.5<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>42.9 and PLCK_G244.8<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>54.9, the putative AGN contribution to the FIR luminosity is below 10%, and it is below 30% in PLCK_G145.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>50.9. In all other cases, <tt>DecompIR </tt>finds the best fit for a pure starburst SED. </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F7\">7</a> also shows the 90% completeness limits of the IRAS faint source survey (<a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R56\">Moshir et al. 1992</a>), 120 mJy and 440 mJy at 60 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 100 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, respectively (green downward arrows). Although these limits are not constraining for the SED fits that we obtained with SPIRE, SCUBA-2, GISMO, and WISE (and were therefore not included in our <tt>DecompIR </tt>fits) they do illustrate that a hypothetical bright quasar component would have led to a 60 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m detection at least in our brightest targets. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F8\">8</a> we illustrate the impact of fiducial AGN contribution of 0.1, 0.3, and <span class=\"simple-math\">0.5 &#215; <i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> on the example of G138.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>62.0, a source with rather average FIR brightness and 250-to-350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m colour in our sample. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p>Infrared-to-millimetre SEDs of all of our 11 sources obtained using <tt>DecompIR </tt>(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R57\">Mullaney et al. 2011</a>). Red dots show our data points, where the error bars along the abscissa indicate the width of each band. The error bars along the ordinate are often smaller than the symbol size. Green downward arrows show the 90% completeness limit of the IRAS all-sky survey at 60 and 100 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, respectively. Red downward arrows at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m show the 5<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> upper limits provided by the WISE catalogs, where the counterparts were fainter than the 5.4 mJy flux limit of the WISE catalog. Black, blue, and yellow lines show the starburst and AGN component (if an AGN was fitted), and the sum of both, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Obviously, these fits are uncertain, given that they cover the far blue wing of the dust SED expected from bright AGN, and a spectral range that has important contributions from rich mid-IR spectral features, in particular from Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAH), which dominate the infrared SEDs of starburst galaxies between about 3 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and 10 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m (e.g., <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R2\">Armus et al. 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>The equivalent widths of the PAH bands have a wide dispersion in high-redshift galaxies (e.g., <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R28\">Fiolet et al. 2010</a>), and are generally larger than those measured in low-redshift ULIRGs, including NGC 7252, which we used as template in our <tt>DecompIR </tt>fits. Additional uncertainties come from the stellar continuum, which reaches comparable strength to the dust continuum in the wavelength range covered by the 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m observations, about 5&#8211;7 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, and whose shape depends strongly on the specific star-formation rate, star-formation history, and geometry of dust obscuration in the host galaxy. Compared to the average mid-IR SED of starburst galaxies (<a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R11\">Brandl et al. 2006</a>), the stellar continuum in NGC 7252 seems relatively faint, and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R74\">Sajina et al. (2012)</a> also found that the mid-IR continuum of high-redshift starburst galaxies seems to be brighter than in low-redshift galaxies. Other spectral features might also contribute to boosting the observed 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m flux density. For example <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R28\">Fiolet et al. (2010)</a> report the detection of warm H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span>line emission at 6.9 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame. Moreover, the foreground galaxies may also contribute to the 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m flux, given the 12<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam of WISE. However, all these uncertainties would only act to lower the putative intrinsic contribution of AGN heating relative to what we observe. It will of course be very interesting to study the mid-IR spectral properties of our sources in depth once that JWST/MIRI will become available. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>A schematic illustrating the impact of 0.1, 0.3, and <span class=\"simple-math\">0.5 &#215;  <i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> of AGN contamination to the shape of the SED of our sources, on the example of G138.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>62.0 and G165.7<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>67.0. </p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Relying upon these arguments, we conclude that the dust heating in our sources is not dominated by heavily obscured quasars, but that the <i>Planck </i>Dusty GEMS are genuine starburst galaxies with at most a minor contribution of AGN heating to the dust emission and the bolometric energy budget of our sources. Of course this only refers to the regions that we are seeing under the gravitational microscope of the foreground lensing systems. The global energy budgets of AGN and star formation in these galaxies may be different, if the AGN lies along a line of sight that is not strongly magnified (see also <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R77\">Serjeant 2012</a>). </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S21\"></a>8. FIR-radio correlation</h2>\n<p>Given the extraordinary brightness of our targets on the sky, we can use the 1.4 GHz VLA survey of the northern sky, FIRST (<a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R4\">Becker et al. 1995</a>), to search for counterparts of our sources at an observed frequency of 1.4 GHz (between 4.5 and 6.4 GHz in the rest-frame). We find that six of our sources have counterparts within 5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> of a source in the FIRST catalogue, and the other five have sensitive upper limits (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T4\">4</a>). Here 5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponds to the beam size of FIRST. We assume a radio spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>1.4</sub> = &#8722;0.8</span> (as is appropriate for star-forming regions, <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R17\">Condon 1992</a>) to convert these flux densities to a monochromatic radio flux density at rest-frame 1.4 GHz, as well as to estimate a radio power. For galaxies without detections we use the 3 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> upper limits implied by the rms given in the FIRST catalogue. Results for individual sources are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T4\">4</a>. All sources are listed in the FIRST catalog as marginally resolved, with deconvolved sizes between 1.5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> and 7<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>. The 5<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> beam of FIRST is not always sufficiently small to rule out contamination from a radio nucleus in the foreground lensing galaxy. However, most sources are isolated enough to conclude that the radio counterpart is at the position of the high-redshift galaxy, and not coincident with a massive, intermediate-redshift galaxy that could host a radio-loud AGN. This is particularly the case for PLCK_G244.8<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>54.9. </p>\n<p>\n        <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4</span></a><p>Radio continuum properties extracted from the FIRST catalogue.</p>\n</div></div>\n      </p>\n<p>The FIR radio correlation is commonly parametrized as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = log&#8201;<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>/ (3.75 &#215; 10<sup>12</sup> W) &#8722; log&#8201;<i>L</i><sub>1.4</sub>/ (W Hz<sup>-1</sup>)</span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span> is measured in the range 8&#8211;1000 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m in the rest-frame, and the centimetre continuum at a rest-frame frequency of 1.4 GHz. Early <i>Herschel </i>results suggest <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>q</i> &#10217;  = 2.4 &#177; 0.12</span> in the local Universe (<a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R44\">Jarvis et al. 2010</a>), although values can change considerably even within individual galaxies (e.g., <a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R87\">Tabatabaei et al. 2013</a>). Towards higher redshifts, results show less of a consensus. <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R47\">Kov&#225;cs et al. (2006)</a>, <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R90\">Vlahakis et al. (2007)</a>, <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R55\">Micha&#322;owski et al. (2010)</a>, and <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R10\">Bourne et al. (2011)</a> report an increase in radio power at a given FIR luminosity at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8819; 1</span>, with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#10216; <i>q</i> &#10217;  = 2.0</span>. However, several studies (e.g., <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R41\">Ivison et al. 2010a</a>,<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R42\">b</a>; <a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R75\">Sargent et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R88\">Thomson et al. 2014</a>) find average values in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span>&#8211;2.7, out to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> &#8776; 2</span>. Most of these studies use stacking analyses to overcome the inherent faintness of high-redshift galaxies in the FIR and sub-mm and in the radio, and are based on ground-based data that do not sample the FIR dust SED very well. In the Cosmic Eyelash, a single, strongly lensed galaxy at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.4</span> with <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>coverage, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R42\">Ivison et al. (2010b)</a> find <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span>. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F9\">9</a> we show where our sources fall relative to the local FIR-radio correlation, assuming that differential lensing between the FIR and radio synchrotron emission does not play a major role in our case. Four of our sources are brighter by up to about 0.4 dex in the radio, and fall outside the 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> scatter around the distribution of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> parameters of low-redshift galaxies. Six galaxies fall within 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> from this relationship, however, three of these galaxies only have upper limits on <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>, and would fall outside the 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> scatter if we had adopted 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span>, instead of 3<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> upper limits. One galaxy has <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i>&gt; 2.7</span> at 3<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span>. </p>\n<p>If the 1.4 GHz emission is caused by star formation, then the lower <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> values cannot be caused by our assumption of the spectral index <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>1.4</sub> = &#8722;0.8</span>. Only for flat radio SEDs (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>1.4</sub> = &#8722;0.2</span> or above, which would only be possible for an AGN) would our highest-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span> sources be consistent with the FIR-correlation and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span>. If this were the case, our sources with the highest <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>parameters (i.e., the brightest sources in the FIR relative to the radio) would fall well above <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 3</span>. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a><p>Far-infrared radio correlation of our sources, as discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S21\">8</a>. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>1.4</sub></span> correspond to the magnification factors appropriate for the dusty and 1.4 GHz synchrotron emission, respectively. Solid blue and red lines show the relationship for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span> and 2.0, respectively, while the red dotted line is for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.7</span>. The dot-dashed lines show the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span>1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> scatter about <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span> at low redshift from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R44\">Jarvis et al. (2010)</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>One way of obtaining lower <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-values, as has been pointed out several times before (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R90\">Vlahakis et al. 2007</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R10\">Bourne et al. 2011</a>) is through radio emission from a central AGN. This has an interesting theoretical aspect, since it has been proposed (e.g., <a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R78\">Silk &amp; Norman 2009</a>) that gas compression caused by expanding radio sources in massive high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies may in fact contribute to boosting the star-formation efficiency in intense high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> starbursts. However, although contamination with nuclear radio emission may be a particular concern for stacking analyses (where one or a few relatively bright radio sources may affect the average result of the overall sample), in our case this explanation seems to be less likely. First, the radio sources are spatially resolved in FIRST, suggesting they are extended, just like the star formation. Even if the Dusty GEMS have extended radio sources, the gravitational lensing would need to amplify the radio emission by similar amounts to that of the star formation in most of our sources; this appears relatively unlikely, given that the AGN radio morphologies of high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies are very different from those of the dust and stellar components (e.g. <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R73\">Sajina et al. 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>As a second counter argument, our SED fits have already disfavoured the presence of very luminous AGN. Although galaxies are known to host central radio sources without bright bolometric emission, the host galaxies of such AGN tend to have little dust, gas, and on-going star formation. And although relatively faint AGN may be present without leaving strong signatures in the dust SEDs, only a subset of those should be radio loud. Even optimistic results (e.g., from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R73\">Sajina et al. 2007</a>), imply that only up to about 30% of dusty high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> starburst galaxies may host moderately bright (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>P</i><sub>1.4</sub> &#8776; 10<sup>25</sup> W Hz<sup>-1</sup></span>, comparable to our sources for magnification factors of order 10) nuclear radio sources that are as bright as or brighter than the star formation itself. In addition, these sources are classified as AGN in the mid-IR. We note that we have not found any obvious trends between the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-parameter and possible probes of AGN contamination like dust temperature or <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span>. We also do not find a correlation between the flux density at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and the 1.4 GHz radio emission. </p>\n<p>As an alternative, the offsets towards larger and smaller <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-parameters may be caused by the star-forming environments themselves. <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R48\">Lacki &amp; Thompson (2010)</a> suggest that enhanced synchrotron emission from cosmic rays in star-forming galaxies at high redshift could be one outcome of the strong turbulence observed in these galaxies (e.g., <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R29\">F&#246;rster Schreiber et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R51\">Lehnert et al. 2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R86\">Swinbank et al. 2011</a>), which enhances the scale height of the gas, and lowers their volume density. In this case, energy loss of cosmic rays through synchrotron radiation, bremsstrahlung, and other processes could be either enhanced or diminished, depending on the local magnetic fields and density distribution of the ISM; this could either decrease or increase the energy losses of the cosmic rays, making our sources either brighter or fainter (e.g., <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R58\">Murphy 2009</a>). Other possible explanations, which might also involve the sources with unusually high <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-parameters, include evolution in the dust properties, the age of the starburst (the radio should not probe starbursts with ages of less than a few times <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>7</sup></span>yr or greater than a few times <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>8</sup></span>yr, because of the timing of core-collapse supernovae, <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R12\">Bressan et al. 2002</a>), and a top-heavy initial mass function (e.g., <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R3\">Baugh et al. 2005</a>). It will be interesting to obtain high-resolution centimetre-wave maps of these sources, along with our gas and dust interferometry, to constrain the potential impact of differential lensing and to further elucidate how the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-parameter depends locally on the ISM properties in our sources. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S22\"></a>9. Gas masses and gas-to-dust ratios</h2>\n<p>To determine the molecular gas mass (which is dominated by H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span>) from the CO luminosity, we have to assume an empirical conversion factor, which is notoriously difficult to justify from first principles, and which is therefore still heavily debated in the literature, in particular for high-redshift galaxies (e.g., <a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R31\">Genzel et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R34\">Glover &amp; Mac Low 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R59\">Narayanan et al. 2012</a>). The canonical value adopted for most high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies is <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i> &#8776; 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup></span>). This value was first derived by <a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R24\">Downes &amp; Solomon (1998)</a> for the dense, circumnuclear, optically thick molecular gas discs in nearby ULIRGs, and is commonly adopted also for dusty starburst galaxies in the early Universe. </p>\n<p>However, several studies in recent years (starting with <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. 2010</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R31\">Genzel et al. 2010</a>) have called into question whether a single CO(1&#8211;0)-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor may be appropriate to use for all high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies. Several attempts have therefore been undertaken to constrain <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> either from dynamical mass estimates, or on theoretical grounds. One empirical approach suited for galaxies with well constrained dust mass measurements like ours, is to assume that high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies fall onto a similar relationship between gas-to-dust mass ratios and metallicities as found for SINGs galaxies in the local Universe (<a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R53\">Leroy et al. 2008</a>). <a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R54\">Magdis et al. (2011)</a> used this approach to confirm their <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> determinations, which they previously obtained from dynamical mass estimates. </p>\n<p>We can use our measurements of the dust mass, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>d</sub></span> (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S16\">6.2</a> and Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T2\">2</a>), and the CO line luminosity, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;</span> (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S12\">4.3</a> and Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T3\">3</a>), to estimate ratios of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;/<i>M</i><sub>d</sub></span>, which scale with gas-phase metallicity (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R53\">Leroy et al. 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R54\">Magdis et al. 2011</a>). Using Fig. 3 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R54\">Magdis et al. (2011)</a>, we find that our measured range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;/<i>M</i><sub>d</sub> = 40</span>&#8211;140 corresponds to gas-phase metallicities <span class=\"simple-math\">12 + log&#8201;(O / H) ~ 8.9&#8722;9.3</span>. These values are appropriate for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#946;</i> = 2.0</span> (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S16\">6.2</a>). Furthermore, we adopted a ratio <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>32 / 10</sub> = 1</span> to convert from the luminosities of the observed mid-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>CO lines to CO(1&#8211;0). This factor is expected for optically thick gas (e.g., <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R80\">Solomon &amp; Vanden Bout 2005</a>). In the Cosmic Eyelash, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R19\">Danielson et al. (2011)</a> measured <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>32 / 10</sub> = 0.7</span>. </p>\n<p>High gas-phase metallicities correspond to small values of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8804; 1.0</span>. For example, if we use the linear fit between <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub></span> and metallicity of <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R32\">Genzel et al. (2012)</a>, we find conversion factors of about 0.4 at face value, although with large uncertainties. Likewise, Fig. 3 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R54\">Magdis et al. (2011)</a> suggests <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> &lt; 1.0 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup></span>) for galaxies with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i>&#8242;/<i>M</i><sub>d</sub></span> ratios and metallicities as high as in our sources. This suggests that using the ULIRG conversion factor of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup></span>) is more appropriate than much higher factors of 3&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\">5 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup></span>), as previously adopted for more moderately star forming, disk-like high-redshift galaxies and the Milky Way. We stress that these results are measured in small regions of high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies, and are not necessarily representative of the average values in these galaxies (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R77\">Serjeant 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>When using a common conversion factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> &#8776; 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span>, we find molecular gas masses of 2&#8211;<span class=\"simple-math\">10 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup><i>&#956;</i><sup>-1</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub></span> for <i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS (including the gravitational magnification factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>). Results for individual galaxies are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#T3\">3</a>. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S23\"></a>10. Integrated star-formation law</h2>\n<p>The tight correlation between molecular gas mass surface density and star-formation intensity over scales of around 100 pc to entire galaxies highlights how star formation depends on the available molecular gas reservoirs (i.e., the Schmidt-Kennicutt law, <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R76\">Schmidt 1959</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R45\">Kennicutt 1998</a>), although there is no consensus about a unique physical mechanism putting this relationship in place. </p>\n<p>However, starting with, e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R31\">Genzel et al. (2010)</a>, several studies have emphasized in recent years that not all high-redshift galaxies may strictly obey the same empirical star-formation law, but that at a given gas surface density, starburst galaxies may be more efficient in turning their gas into stars. The reasons for this are still unclear, with possibilities ranging from changes in the stellar initial mass function (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R3\">Baugh et al. 2005</a>) to different star-formation efficiencies. For example, there may be more star-forming clouds in their ISM than in more quiescent high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies (<a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R52\">Lehnert et al. 2013</a>), or the star-formation efficiency per free-fall time could be higher (<a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R20\">Dekel et al. 2009</a>). What we can confidently assert (given the absence of dust with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i> &#8811; 50 </span>K, faint 22-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m flux density, or excess radio emission) is that AGN do not play a dominant role in boosting the FIR continuum in the strongly amplified regions that we are seeing in our galaxies (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S18\">7</a>). Given the close astrophysical connection between dust and gas in star-forming regions, we see no reason to believe that differential lensing plays an important role for our analysis of the gas conditions in the regions, which are amplified by the gravitational lenses. Of course, we must keep in mind that the gas and dust measurements obtained in small, selectively amplified regions of these galaxies are not necessarily representative of the average gas and dust properties in these galaxies on global scales (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R77\">Serjeant 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>The relationship of FIR luminosity with CO line luminosity is a simple, empirical, and robust way of investigating this &#8220;star-formation law&#8221;. It is directly related to the integral form of the Schmidt-Kennicutt law, because the FIR luminosity probing the emission from warm dust is an excellent tracer of star formation. CO line emission is mainly excited through collisions with H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> and is the most commonly adopted proxy of the total molecular gas mass (e.g., <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R65\">Omont 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>In order to investigate whether our sources are representative of star formation in high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> starburst galaxies or more ordinary, but nonetheless very intensely star-forming galaxies on the &#8220;main sequence&#8221; (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R27\">Elbaz et al. 2011</a>), we use the molecular gas masses estimated from the CO luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>H2</sub></span>) and FIR luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span>), shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F10\">10</a>, and compare with the correlations found by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R31\">Genzel et al. (2010)</a> for starburst galaxies, together with the more gradually, but nonetheless intensely star-forming high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies on the &#8220;main sequence&#8221;. For this comparison, we use the integrated star-formation rates and molecular gas masses, adopting <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> as justified in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S22\">9</a>. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a><p>Infrared luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>) as a function of molecular gas mass for our sources. Red, yellow, and purple stars indicate the measured values (uncorrected for gravitational amplification), and the same values corrected by fiducial lensing factors of 10 and 50, respectively. In agreement with the dust-to-gas ratios discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S22\">9</a> we adopt the classical &#8220;ULIRG&#8221; conversion factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> for all sources. The blue and red line indicate the relationships for starbursts and &#8220;main-sequence&#8221; galaxies emphasized by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a>. Small dots show the low- and high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> samples of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a> for comparison. Light blue dots along the upper line show low- and high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> ULIRGs and SMGs, respectively. The filled dark green dots (with error bars) are <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>BzK</i></span> galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span>; for details of these samples see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a>. All error bars include the measurement uncertainties. The black cross in the lower right corner of the plot shows a fiducial factor 2 in statistical uncertainty.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>We find that all sources fall closer to the upper &#8220;starburst&#8221; than the lower &#8220;main sequence&#8221; lines in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F10\">10</a>. To illustrate the effects of lensing, i.e., how these sources might appear in the image plane, we plot not only the observed luminosities (red filled stars), but also the luminosities for fiducial magnification factors <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 10</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i> = 50</span> (orange and light blue empty stars in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F10\">10</a>). Even without the detailed lens modelling their position in the diagram relative to typical starburst or main-sequence galaxies does not depend sensitively on the precise magnification factor. </p>\n<p>We stress that in the present study, we only show integrated measurements, whereas the relationship that underlies the Schmidt-Kennicutt diagram is between the surface density of molecular gas mass and the star-formation rate. Our on-going interferometric follow-up programme will enable us to derive more detailed constraints, and to investigate whether the &#8220;starburst&#8221; and &#8220;main sequence&#8221; classifications are unique for each source, or whether each individual Dusty GEM will show a range in star-formation efficiency. </p>\n<p>FIR luminosities and gas mass estimates also provide simple, rough constraints on the gas depletion timescale, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>dpl</sub> = <i>M</i><sub>gas</sub></span>/SFR, and hence the time during which the current star formation intensity can be maintained without replenishing the molecular gas reservoirs. Assuming that star-formation rates are constant, we find short gas depletion timescales, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>t</i><sub>dpl</sub> = (0.5&#8722;6) &#215; 10<sup>7</sup></span>yr, significantly less than the typical stellar age of a FIR or sub-mm galaxy (a few times <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>8</sup></span> yr, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R79\">Smail et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R50\">Lapi et al. 2012</a>), and also somewhat, but not dramatically, shorter than the gas depletion timescales found for unlensed sub-mm galaxies (e.g., <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R35\">Greve et al. 2005</a>). This highlights again the fact that our sources have all the hallmarks of being &#8220;ordinary&#8221; dusty starburst galaxies placed under particularly powerful cosmic microscopes. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S24\"></a>11. Summary</h2>\n<p>We have presented a first analysis of an extensive multi-wavelength follow-up campaign of a new sample of the brightest high-redshift FIR and sub-mm galaxies, discovered through the unique synergy of the <i>Planck </i>and <i>Herschel </i>satellites. <i>Planck</i>&#8217;s all-sky nature and multi-frequency coverage allows us to select rare peaks in the sub-mm background and <i>Herschel </i>observations lead to subsample of strongly lensed candidates &#8211; <i>Planck</i>&#8217;s Dusty GEMS. Their FIR peak flux densities are up to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>S</i><sub>350</sub> = 1130 </span>mJy at 350 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, including six sources that are above the completeness limit of <i>Planck </i>at the highest frequencies. Our sample extends the very successful searches for gravitationally lensed high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies already carried out with <i>Herschel </i>and the SPT towards the brightest, rarest targets on the FIR and sub-mm sky, which emphasized the need for a genuine all-sky survey to systematically probe such exceedingly uncommon sources. </p>\n<p>All sources in our sample are bright, isolated point sources in SPIRE 250-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m maps (18<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> FWHM), and have the typical FIR-to-mm SEDs of dusty, intensely star-forming galaxies at high redshift. They have redshifts in the range <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 2.2</span>&#8211;3.6, based on multiple bright millimetre emission lines obtained with EMIR at the IRAM 30-m telescope. Their dust and gas properties provide firm evidence that they are indeed gravitationally lensed galaxies, as is further supported through interferometric observations of their dust and gas morphologies, already obtained for most sources. </p>\n<p>We used the WISE survey at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m and the 1.4 GHz VLA FIRST survey to show that the FIR continuum of the Dusty GEMS is not dominated by the radiation of powerful AGN. In particular, we find that buried quasars cannot make a dominant contribution to their observed FIR SEDs. All SEDs are well fitted with a single modified blackbody distribution with temperatures <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>T</i><sub>d</sub> = 33</span>&#8211;50 K, covering the range of high-redshift starburst galaxies, as well as more gradually, but still intensely star-forming, high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies on the &#8220;main sequence&#8221;. They show a wide scatter about the local FIR radio correlation, with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i></span>-parameters ranging from 2.0, as has previously been found for high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> galaxies by some authors, to above 2.7, which suggests a considerable excess of FIR relative to synchrotron emission. One plausible interpretation is that this is probably a consequence of their turbulent ISM, but this needs to be confirmed through more detailed studies comparing the resolved radio emission with other source properties. All galaxies have gas-to-dust ratios of 40&#8211;140, consistent with a low CO-to-H<span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>2</sub></span> conversion factor, as expected for massive, dusty starburst galaxies with metallicities above solar. A full analysis of the spatially resolved properties of these galaxies, as well as detailed lens modelling, is on-going. </p>\n<p>Strongly lensed high-redshift sub-mm galaxies represent an excellent opportunity to study gas heating and acceleration, and the mechanism driving star formation in the most vigorous starbursts in the early Universe. Detailed observations of the dust, stellar populations, and multiple emission and absorption lines, in particular with sub-mm and millimetre interferometry have already been obtained and will be discussed in future papers. </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><i>Herschel </i>is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> See the SPIRE Handbook 2014, <a href=\"http://herschel.esac.esa.int/Docs/SPIRE/spire_handbook.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">http://herschel.esac.esa.int/Docs/SPIRE/spire_handbook.pdf</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/%20scipy.optimize.curve_fit.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/ scipy.optimize.curve_fit.html</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN10\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">\n          <a href=\"http://www.rssd.esa.int/index.php?project=PLANCK&amp;page=Planck_Collaboration\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.rssd.esa.int/index.php?project=PLANCK&amp;page=Planck_Collaboration</a>\n        </p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>We would like to thank the staff at the IRAM 30-m telescope, in particular N. Contours show the <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>morphology at 250 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a><p>Near-infrared <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span>-band images of the nine sources from Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F1\">1</a>. Contours show the SMA morphology at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m. The FWHM beam size of all SMA data is about 2<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> (the FWHM beam size is shown in the bottom left corner of each panel), except for PLCK_G080.2<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>49.8, where it is 0.8<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a><p>Lowest-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>J</i></span> CO emission line in each of our targets. CO(3&#8211;2) and CO(4&#8211;3) are indicated in yellow and green, respectively. Red dotted lines show simple single-Gaussian fits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a><p>Modified blackbody fits to the FIR-to-millimetre photometry of our sources as obtained with <i>Herschel-SPIRE </i>at 250, 350, and 500 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, with JCMT/SCUBA-2 at 850 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m (for eight sources), and with IRAM/Gismo at 2 mm. The light and dark blue curves show the blackbody curves for optically thin and optically thick dust, respectively. Error bars are printed in black, and are smaller than the symbols showing the photometric data points.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a><p>Characterizing our sources by their FIR luminosities, dust temperatures, and redshifts. <i>Top</i>: FIR luminosities versus dust temperatures. The Dusty GEMS targets are shown as red stars on top of the comparison samples of strongly lensed sources taken from the literature (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R36\">Greve et al. 2012</a>, and references therein), lens candidates from the SPT survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R89\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>), the Eyelash (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R42\">Ivison et al. 2010b</a>), and the two <i>Planck </i>lenses that were discovered prior to our work (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R16\">Combes et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R30\">Fu et al. 2012</a>). The solid line shows a fit to the general population, while the dotted lines show magnification factors of 10 and 50. <i>Bottom</i>: FIR luminosity as a function of redshift. In the lower panel, our sources fall near the most luminous gravitationally lensed galaxies at similar redshifts; however, these are strongly dominated by AGN, like APM 08279<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>5255, whereas our sources are bona fide starbursts, at least in the image plane. This explains the greater luminosities at lower dust temperatures seen in the top panel.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a><p><i>Top</i>: order-of-magnitude estimate of the gravitational magnification factor derived from the dust temperature and FIR luminosity of our sources compared to FIR and sub-mm galaxies in the field (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S16\">6.2</a> for details). <i>Bottom</i>: CO emission-line luminosity as a function of FWHM line width, using the same symbols as in the top panel, with additional light blue dots showing those sources of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R9\">Bothwell et al. (2013)</a>, which are neither gravitationally lensed nor AGN hosts. The solid and dashed lines show the best linear fit to the sample of field galaxies, as well as shifts of this line corresponding to magnification factors of 5, 10, and 20. Error bars show the 1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> uncertainties of our single-component Gaussian line fits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a><p>Infrared-to-millimetre SEDs of all of our 11 sources obtained using <tt>DecompIR </tt>(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R57\">Mullaney et al. 2011</a>). Red dots show our data points, where the error bars along the abscissa indicate the width of each band. The error bars along the ordinate are often smaller than the symbol size. Green downward arrows show the 90% completeness limit of the IRAS all-sky survey at 60 and 100 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m, respectively. Red downward arrows at 22 <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>m show the 5<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> upper limits provided by the WISE catalogs, where the counterparts were fainter than the 5.4 mJy flux limit of the WISE catalog. Black, blue, and yellow lines show the starburst and AGN component (if an AGN was fitted), and the sum of both, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a><p>A schematic illustrating the impact of 0.1, 0.3, and <span class=\"simple-math\">0.5 &#215;  <i>L</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> of AGN contamination to the shape of the SED of our sources, on the example of G138.6<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>62.0 and G165.7<span class=\"simple-math\">+</span>67.0. </p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a><p>Far-infrared radio correlation of our sources, as discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S21\">8</a>. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>FIR</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i><sub>1.4</sub></span> correspond to the magnification factors appropriate for the dusty and 1.4 GHz synchrotron emission, respectively. Solid blue and red lines show the relationship for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span> and 2.0, respectively, while the red dotted line is for <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.7</span>. The dot-dashed lines show the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span>1<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i></span> scatter about <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>q</i> = 2.4</span> at low redshift from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R44\">Jarvis et al. (2010)</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F9\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a><p>Infrared luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>IR</sub></span>) as a function of molecular gas mass for our sources. Red, yellow, and purple stars indicate the measured values (uncorrected for gravitational amplification), and the same values corrected by fiducial lensing factors of 10 and 50, respectively. In agreement with the dust-to-gas ratios discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#S22\">9</a> we adopt the classical &#8220;ULIRG&#8221; conversion factor <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/ (K km s<sup>-1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>)</span> for all sources. The blue and red line indicate the relationships for starbursts and &#8220;main-sequence&#8221; galaxies emphasized by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a>. Small dots show the low- and high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> samples of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a> for comparison. Light blue dots along the upper line show low- and high-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i></span> ULIRGs and SMGs, respectively. The filled dark green dots (with error bars) are <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>BzK</i></span> galaxies at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> ~ 2</span>; for details of these samples see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#R18\">Daddi et al. (2010)</a>. All error bars include the measurement uncertainties. The black cross in the lower right corner of the plot shows a fiducial factor 2 in statistical uncertainty.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2015/09/aa25128-14/aa25128-14.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201425128\" data-edps_ref=\"aa25128-14\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015.
